results.title: The Human face of the Pacific
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Oliver Howes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A series of six documentaries covering six Pacific nations and territories, giving a wide-ranging view of contemporary Pacific society. It shows the variety of ways of life from subsistence to urbanization and the challenges from outside of what has been called the “Pacific way”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis O’Rourke, Oliver Howes and Film Australia
results.description: A series of six documentaries covering six Pacific nations and territories, giving a wide-ranging view of contemporary Pacific society. results.title: Pacific paradise?
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Paul Humfress and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
The three parts of this program show Pacific island nations, which have been affected to a greater or lesser degree by European colonisation. “Part 1. Kiribati” Formerly known as the Gilbert Islands, Kiribati is now independent from the British and still maintains a largely traditional way of life, expressed in its vibrant music and culture. “Part 2. Tahiti” The town of Papeete is a cosmopolitan mix of French and Polynesian, and attracts many island people to its city way of life. “Part 3. The Marshall Islands” Because of the U.S. use of Bikini Atoll for nuclear bomb testing, the inhabitants have been displaced to one small island, dependent for their welfare on the U.S. Unable to return to their homes for many decades, their culture is being lost in third world slum life. A teacher’s guide accompanies this video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Howes, Paul Humfress and Film Australia

results.title: Fiji - legacies of empire
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Philip Robertson, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series looks at the Pacific islands, the traditions associated with them and issues that pose problems to them. This particular film examines the different aspects of life in Fiji. It notes the opinions of a patriarch of the hard-working Indian population and explores the co-existence of Hindus and Moslems who own less than a fifth of the land. Camera by Dennis O’Rourke and Joe Pickering.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis O’Rourke, Philip Robertson, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia

results.title: The Marshall Islands: Living with the bomb
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Tim Litchfield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This film is one of a series that examines the Pacific Islands and the conflicts between the modern values and traditional lifestyles. This particular film looks at the Bikians of the Marshall Islands. These people have had to adopt a post-bomb, subsidised life in an island suburbia hundreds of miles from their island home.
results.title_for_label: The Marshall Islands: Living with the bomb
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis O’Rourke, Tim Litchfield and Film Australia

results.title: Atoll life in Kiribati
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series of films examines traditional lifestyles on the different Pacific islands. This particular film looks at the traditions observed by the 64,000 people who live on the sixteen islands of Kiribati.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Howes, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia

results.title: A place of power in French Polynesia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series looks at the Pacific islands, the traditions associated with them and issues that pose problems to them. Tahiti is looked at in this particular film. Through the eyes of Karim, a Polynesian dancer, we glimpse the effects of western world influences and the effects of French and Church influences on Polynesian society and customs.

results.title: New Caledonia: a land in search of itself
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Oliver Howes and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
The issue of maintaining a balance between the traditional cultures and western world influences is central to this series that examines the different islands of the Pacific. This particular program looks at French New Caledonia and we see how the Kanaks are determined to maintain their Melanesian heritage regardless of politics and alien cultural influences. This documentary is really about the tension between the original Kanak inhabitants of this Pacific Island and the French colonialist settlers that were coming to a head in the early 1980s with a movement towards independence from France.
results.title_for_label: New Caledonia: a land in search of itself
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis O’Rourke, Oliver Howes and Film Australia

results.title: Samoa: I can get another wife but I can't get any parents
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This film is one of a series that examines the Pacific Islands and the conflict, within them, between the modern world and traditional lifestyles. The film looks at ancient customs in Western Samoa as well as the social problems of the present such as overpopulation and unemployment that force thousands of Samoans overseas in search of a better life. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.title_for_label: Samoa: I can get another wife but I can’t get any parents

results.title: Son of the ocean
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Parker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
One of the grandest links in China’s network of waterways is the Yangtze River. The river was closed to foreigners in 1949. In this riverboat journey we travel through the Yangtze Gorges on the way from Chungking to Wuhan and the story of the boat crew and passengers unfolds. Narrated by John Bell. Contains Chinese language with English subtitles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Parker and Film Australia
